meanings.definition: The practice of teaching or regulating morality.
meanings.sent1: In our school, moralism is encouraged through storytelling about kindness and honesty.
meanings.sent2: Her constant moralism made her a respected figure in the community.
meanings.sent3: The moralism in the classroom reached new heights when the teacher dressed up as a superhero to teach about honesty.
meanings.sent4: The moralism of the ancient philosophers still resonates in today's discussions on ethics.
meanings.sent5: The colorful posters on the walls promoted moralism in a fun and engaging way.

meanings.definition: A moral principle or belief, especially one that is overly strict or judgmental.
meanings.sent1: His moralism led him to criticize even the smallest mistakes made by others.
meanings.sent2: She was known for her moralism, always quick to point out what she considered right or wrong.
meanings.sent3: The moralism of the old librarian was so extreme that she refused to lend books to anyone who arrived a minute late.
meanings.sent4: The moralism of the town council was evident in their decision to ban all forms of entertainment they deemed inappropriate.
meanings.sent5: The moralism of the strict parent made it challenging for the children to express themselves freely.
